text.p: Shareholders of Polish trading and industrial firm Elektrim SA approved on Friday a 550 million zloty ($183.3 million) convertible bond issue, which will be managed by Merrill Lynch International and Poland's Bank Pekao SA.

Elektrim deputy president and chief financial officer Piotr Mroczkowski told a news briefing after shareholders' meeting the funds from the seven-year-bond issue would help pay off bank loans and finance investments in the energy sector.
"The main goal (of the issue) is to shift from bank loans into other sources of financing...and to finance our planned activities in energy sector," Mroczkowski said.
He said Elektrim's bank loans amounted to $120 million.
Elektrim's shareholders also approved an issue of up to 19 million new shares ex-rights to be exchanged for the bonds.
Mroczkowski said Elektrim's management would later decide details of the bond.
The offer will be Poland's biggest convertible bond issue to date.
He said Elektrim wanted to attract investors, both domestic and foreign, who would seek to exchange the bonds and acquire a stake in the company rather than redeem the papers at maturity.
"We have three currencies to choose from: the zloty, the dollar and the Deutschmark, dollar surely not because it's firming now, for now it would be either zloty or mark," Mroczkowski said.
He said Elektrim planned to list the bonds on the Luxembourg exchange and the new shares on the Warsaw bourse.
The new shares' issue price will initially be equal to that on the listed shares plus a premium of no more than 15 percent.
He said Elektrim wanted to place the bonds by the end of May before expected big-ticket privatisations hit the markets.

The company's president Andrzej Skowronski, also present, said Elektrim wanted to start preparing for privatisations in Poland's energy sector before any tenders are announced so it wins a headstart on competition.
He added Elektrim also wanted to participate in the expansion and restructuring of Poland's power plants.
